fields.intro: Dental implant surgery is a procedure that replaces tooth roots with metal, screwlike posts and replaces damaged or missing teeth with artificial teeth that look and function much like real ones. Dental implant surgery can offer a welcome alternative to dentures or bridgework that doesn't fit well and can offer an option when a lack of natural teeth roots don't allow building denture or bridgework tooth replacements.

Tooth decay, also known as dental caries, is the process by which acids produced by bacteria erode the hard tissues of the tooth. It begins when plaque—a sticky film of bacteria—builds up on the surface of the teeth. If not removed through regular brushing and flossing, plaque interacts with sugars from food to produce acid, leading to the breakdown of the enamel, the outermost layer of the tooth.
fields.body:
[{"type": "html", "value": "

What is Tooth Decay?

Tooth decay, also known as dental caries, is the process by which acids produced by bacteria erode the hard tissues of the tooth. It begins when plaque—a sticky film of bacteria—builds up on the surface of the teeth. If not removed through regular brushing and flossing, plaque interacts with sugars from food to produce acid, leading to the breakdown of the enamel, the outermost layer of the tooth.

Over time, this process can extend deeper into the tooth, causing cavities and more severe dental issues. Early detection of tooth decay is crucial to prevent long-term damage.

", "id": "2613ecc2-fdb4-4476-ab21-5e8e3d1f69e7"}, {"type": "html", "value": "

Tooth decay progression (Dental caries) by Ebers on Sketchfab

", "id": "f55fd669-936c-4105-a873-1eb9c49b7e03"}, {"type": "html", "value": "

Stages of Tooth Decay

Stage 1: Enamel Demineralization

The first stage of tooth decay starts with the demineralization of enamel. This stage often shows as white spots on the surface of the tooth. At this point, decay can be reversed through improved oral hygiene and fluoride treatments.

Stage 2: Cavities in Enamel and Dentin

If the enamel continues to break down, a cavity, or hole, forms in the tooth. The decay then progresses into the dentin, the softer layer underneath the enamel, leading to more significant damage and potential sensitivity to hot or cold temperatures.

Stage 3: Pulp Infection and Abscess

In advanced cases, the decay reaches the tooth's pulp, causing severe pain and infection. At this stage, the tooth may require a root canal to remove the infected tissue or, in extreme cases, extraction to prevent further health complications.

Common Symptoms of Tooth Decay

Tooth decay can manifest in various ways, including sensitivity to hot or cold foods and beverages, tooth pain, and bad breath. Visible symptoms include dark spots, pits, or holes in the tooth surface. If left untreated, tooth decay can lead to serious complications, including abscesses and tooth loss.

", "id": "a9d62180-9ba5-4afc-9768-ff60ad9de57a"}]

fields.intro: After receiving zirconium crowns, many patients are advised to wear a night guard to protect their new dental restorations. Zirconium crowns are known for their strength and durability, but like all dental work, they still require proper care and protection, especially during nighttime when teeth grinding and clenching can occur. In this blog, we will explore the importance of wearing a night guard after zirconium installation and how it can extend the life of your dental restorations.
fields.body:
[{"type": "html", "value": "

What is a Night Guard?

A night guard is a custom-made dental appliance worn over the teeth to prevent grinding (bruxism) or clenching, particularly during sleep. This device acts as a protective barrier between the upper and lower teeth, absorbing the pressure and preventing damage to the crowns or natural teeth.

", "id": "47e9cdbc-46d9-4478-854e-af0e7115f20a"}, {"type": "html", "value": "

Dental Aligner by FunctionalResearch_3D on Sketchfab

", "id": "68375fdd-b2f5-4671-a63f-94d921235b59"}, {"type": "html", "value": "

Why a Night Guard is Essential After Zirconium Installation

1. Protects Against Teeth Grinding

Teeth grinding is a common problem, often occurring unconsciously during sleep. Over time, this habit can wear down zirconium crowns, even though zirconium is a tough material. A night guard provides a protective layer that minimizes direct contact between teeth, reducing the risk of grinding-induced damage to your crowns.

2. Prevents Excessive Pressure on Crowns

Zirconium crowns, while incredibly strong, are not indestructible. When you clench your teeth, it can place significant pressure on the crowns. This excessive force could eventually lead to cracks or fractures in the crowns. A night guard helps to distribute the pressure evenly across your teeth, protecting the crowns from undue stress.

3. Extends the Lifespan of Your Dental Work

Investing in a night guard can prolong the life of your zirconium crowns. By reducing the impact of grinding and clenching, the guard ensures that your crowns remain in optimal condition for many years. Without a night guard, the constant wear and tear on the crowns could result in the need for costly repairs or replacements sooner than expected.

", "id": "12c9e179-226d-4c39-b227-ee6417a70960"}]
